author: Roxanne Elias
title: 'Come prepared': Drivers urge caution as snowy conditions create problems on Interstate 80
text:
PLACER COUNTY, Calif. — [Stormy conditions](/weather/) on Interstate 80 are causing havoc for drivers who had to sit in traffic for hours after a big rig crash.
It started around 1:30 p.m. when traffic was held on westbound I-80 after the crash at Whitmore. Several drivers pulled over at the Nyack exit instead of sitting in the standstill traffic.
“I was on my way back up to San Francisco for my office holiday party,” said Tom Gump, who was driving from Tahoe. “In a world of back to office, it was going to be a great time to get together and enjoy the holiday season. I cannot believe that we're stuck here not knowing how long it's going to continue and before we're able to go again.”
Gump says it’s not the first time something like that’s happened to him. He was stuck at the same location for about 16 hours four years ago.
“A big rig that was carrying milk jackknifed (and) dumped all of its milk on the ground and they were treating it as hazardous material that needed to be cleaned up, so I'm cautiously optimistic we're not going to be here 16 hours today,” Gump told [ABC10](/).
[Caltrans](https://dot.ca.gov/) is expecting the weather to take a break during the day Friday, but snowy conditions could pick up Friday night going into Saturday, and that’s when people could see more accidents or spinouts, so they want drivers to be ready for delays.
“Just be prepared. You know, pack chains, even if four-wheel drive/all-wheel drive. We recommend that you pack chains just in case and then bring blankets with you. Bring flashlights, make sure your phone is charged. Make sure your gas tank’s full,” said John O’Connell with Caltrans.
As a safety precaution, semitruck drivers like Jason Dennis also want people to look out for them when they must chain up.
“My biggest concern is the cars drive by, and they don't pay attention to the truck drivers, and they come close to hitting us every time we're putting chains on,” said Dennis.
Earlier Thursday, some drivers were caught off guard by the snow going up the mountain, but they plan to make the most of it. Still, they recommend others check the conditions before hitting the Sierra this weekend.
“Just slow down, be careful. (It) makes me nervous with the kids,” said Melody Burns.
Caltrans says anyone coming through the area should check the [QuickMap website](https://quickmap.dot.ca.gov/) or app. It has the latest on chain controls, access to traffic cameras and information about lane closings.
“Come prepared. Just because you think it may not be, it might be,” said Thomas Burns.

author: María Marta Guzmán
title: From Ukraine to Knoxville: UT violinist who fled war will soon cross graduation stage
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — From Ukraine to Knoxville — the sound of a violin followed Marki Lukyniuk wherever he went. He arrived in Knoxville as a refugee, after Russia invaded Ukraine and began around two years of intense fighting. That never stopped him from playing violin, though, and he brought his music across the world. "Violin is just something that I've been playing since I can remember myself," he said. "It's been to Italy, Germany, France, Austria, Poland, gosh, in the U.S." He is only 23 years old but captivated the hearts of East Tennesseans during his performances. He performed at hundreds of events and produced his own music, making his mark on Rocky Top through creativity and talent. "I showed people something that they never saw before, and never heard before," he said. "It's a part of me." He said he started playing when he was around 5 years old, and the instrument eventually helped him find a one-way ticket to the U.S. He arrived in 2022 after fleeing the war, hoping to continue his education. "I knew that it's not safe to stay in my country, and I wanted to finish my bachelor's degree. I wanted to pursue music," he said. He has performed at benefit concerts, raising money to support Ukraine. Despite being so far away from home, he embraced his roots. "To show people how beautiful Ukraine is, and how much talent we have," he said. "I would like to thank everybody who kept supporting me, I'm going to miss you guys." He said after graduating from the University of Tennessee's School of Music, he plans to attend the University of Miami as he pursues a master's degree. Spring commencement will start on May 16, when students will start walking across the stage claiming their degrees. It will go through May 20 and will take place in the Food City Center.

author: The Bridge Desk
title: Rabies claims state-level kabaddi player's life after he ignored a dog bite
text:
Kabaddi
Rabies claims state-level kabaddi player's life after he ignored a dog bite
Brijesh Solanki, a state-level kabaddi player, was bitten by a dog he rescued three months back.
A state-level kabaddi player, Brijesh Solanki, passed away due to rabies in Uttar Pradesh’s Bulandshahr. According to reports, he was bitten by a dog he rescued three months back from a drain.
He, however, ignored that bite and did not go for a rabies vaccination, thinking that it was a minor injury, which later troubled him and caused his death.
His coach, Praveen Kumar, told, “Brijesh mistook the pain in his arm for a regular kabaddi injury. The bite seemed minor and he didn’t think it was serious, so he didn’t take the vaccine," as reported by the Times of India.
Brijesh complained of numbness during a practice session last week and was taken to a district hospital, but his condition worsened, and he was transferred to a private hospital in Noida.
A few videos before his death show Brijesh in severe pain, and in one clip, he is seen enduring a violent rabies attack.
Sandeep Kumar, his brother, claimed that Brijesh was denied treatment at multiple government hospitals.
“All of a sudden, he was afraid of water and was showing symptoms of rabies, but we were denied treatment at the government hospitals in Khurja, Aligarh, and even Delhi. It was only in Noida that doctors confirmed he was likely infected with rabies. Brijesh died on Saturday while we were taking him to a faith healer in Mathura," he told TOI.
Brijesh was a resident of Farana village in Bulandshahr. The entire village assembled to bid a final farewell to the beloved kabaddi player.

author: Gregory Melton
title: What city did God destroy?
text:
What city did God destroy?
In the Abrahamic religions, Sodom and Gomorrah were two cities destroyed by God for their wickedness. Their story parallels the Genesis flood narrative in its theme of God’s anger provoked by man’s sin.
1. What was the sinful city that God destroyed?
The sinful city that God destroyed was Sodom and Gomorrah.
2. What is Sodom and Gomorrah called today?
Har Sedom, or Mount Sodom, is the present-day name for the location of Sodom and Gomorrah.
3. How was Sodom and Gomorrah destroyed?
According to the Book of Genesis, God rained brimstone and fire upon Sodom and Gomorrah from heaven, causing the destruction of the cities.
4. Was Sodom and Gomorrah destroyed by a volcano?
While Sodom and Gomorrah were most probably destroyed by a strong earthquake or flood, there are theories that the fresh memory of a volcanic eruption may have merged with the story of their destruction.
5. What is the cursed city in the Bible?
Sodom is often referred to as the cursed city in the Bible due to its wickedness and subsequent destruction.
6. Where is Sodom and Gomorrah today?
Sodom and Gomorrah are believed to have been located in the Ghor or valley of the Jordan, in the modern-day Kingdom of Jordan.
7. Where is the city of Sodom today?
The city of Sodom may have been discovered by archaeologists working on a site in Jordan near the Dead Sea.
8. What does the Quran say about Sodom and Gomorrah?
According to the Quran, the people of Sodom and Gomorrah ignored the messages of the prophet Lut and were subsequently destroyed by God.
9. Does Sodom and Gomorrah still exist?
There is no concrete evidence of the existence of Sodom and Gomorrah, and their exact locations have not been discovered.
10. Was there a real Sodom and Gomorrah?
There is no consensus among archaeologists, scientists, and Biblical scholars regarding the existence of Sodom and Gomorrah.
11. What does Gomorrah mean in the Bible?
Gomorrah is one of the two ancient cities near the Dead Sea, along with Sodom, that were destroyed by God as punishment for the wickedness of their inhabitants.
12. Why did Lot’s wife look back?
Lot’s wife looked back as they were fleeing Sodom against the warning given by God. As a result, she was turned into a pillar of salt.
13. Why did God flood the world?
The story of the flood in the Book of Genesis depicts God’s decision to intervene and destroy the world due to its corruption, violence, and wickedness.
14. Has the city of Sodom been discovered?
There are claims that the location of the original city of Sodom has been discovered in Jordan based on archaeological excavations at the Tall el Hammam site.
15. Where is Garden of Eden located today?
The exact location of the Garden of Eden is unknown, with various suggestions being made, including locations at the head of the Persian Gulf, southern Mesopotamia, and Armenia.
16. Where is Lot’s wife Pillar of Salt located?
The Pillar of Salt, associated with Lot’s wife, is said to be located near the Dead Sea at Mount Sodom in Jordan.
17. What does Sodom mean in the Bible?
Sodom, in the Old Testament, refers to one of the two ancient cities near the Dead Sea that were destroyed by God for their wickedness.
18. Why was Lot’s wife turned to salt?
Lot’s wife was turned into a pillar of salt because she disobeyed the warning not to look back at the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah.
19. Is Ethiopia in the Bible?
Ethiopia is mentioned in various parts of the Hebrew Bible and is often used interchangeably with Cush, with later identification with Nubia and Aksum.
20. Why did God destroy Babylon?
God intervened and destroyed Babylon due to its sin and wickedness, as part of His righteous character.
21. What is the Gomorrah?
Gomorrah, also known as Gomorrha, refers to one of the two ancient cities near the Dead Sea, along with Sodom, that were destroyed by God for their wickedness.
22. Why is Pompeii called Sin city?
Pompeii is called Sin city because it was a city characterized by violent passions, sexual appetites, unrestrained ambition, and creative genius that came to a tragic end with the eruption of Mount Vesuvius.

author: Robin Caudell Press-Republican
title: Bishop of Ogdensburg shares Easter message
text:
PLATTSBURGH — Today, Christians observe Good Friday also known as Great Friday, Holy Friday and Black Friday, which commemorates Jesus Christ’s crucifixion and death at Calvary, whose exact location is not known outside of Jerusalem.
Below Diocese of Ogdensburg Most Reverend Bishop Terry R. LaValley shares his message for Easter 2024.
“I am the resurrection and the life, the one who believes in me, though he or she die, yet shall they live, and whoever lives and believes in me shall never die.”
Dear Sisters and Brothers in Christ:
Yes, the Lord has risen! Satan did all he could to break down the love, courage, and fidelity of our Savior. Evil unleashed its arsenal of hatred, injustice, humiliation, and pain. Evil fought a bloody fight, but the Son of God rose victorious. That means absolutely everything for you and me!
The resurrection is the sacred stamp that validates everything Jesus did and said: His claim to be God’s Son; His insistence of authority to forgive sin; His universal call to abandon self- centeredness for love of God and neighbor as the path to true happiness and everlasting peace; and His promise to send the Holy Spirit for guidance to His Mystical Body, our Church.
Jesus was not one more person who finished last, one more dreamer whose dreams were squelched by the harsh reality of life on this earth. Jesus Christ has risen! Jesus’ victory over evil and lies; over injustice and suffering is total and irreversible. In the face of over twenty centuries filled with a steady stream of saints, no reasonable person can deny it.
Let there be no mistake. Evil still wanders about. However, we remain ever vigilant and grateful for the gifts of the Spirit on our earthly journeys. We share this Good News and express our resurrection joy, even amid today’s trials and tribulation. Christ’s victory over sin and death causes us to always be hope-filled pilgrims of faith because we are Christ-led and Christ-fed.
Alleluia! Blessed Easter to you and your loved ones! Alleluia!
Faithfully yours in Christ,
Most Reverend Terry R. LaValley
Bishop of Ogdensburg
